title: Ultimaker frame holds up to 4 cassettes (v.2)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is version 2 of our work to equip the Ultimaker 3D printer with up to 4 exchangeable 'cassettes'. For v.1 and development rationale, see Thing 25836: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25836. For this version, we decided to use 3D-printed parts alongside birchwood. (Developed at Protospace Utrecht with help from Douwe van der Veen/appultaart</i?)

For general instructions, see the prior version of this Thing at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25836. In short: use a lasercutter to cut the parts in the .svg file from 4mm wood.
use a 3D-printer to print the plastic part that is present in the .stl file. Mount all together, and use a 3mm metal screwpin (which is a standard part of the Ultimaker extruder head) to adjust height. Please share advise or suggestions regarding the height adjustment mechanism.

title: Printrbot Plus v2.1 Dual Spool Holder/Top Rail Support

description.text: These were actually my first print designs and I am still using them now after printing quite a few other pieces.  So be merciful...I know the tower piece can be modded to something cooler but what I've got works just fine, the holder is legit though.

Print Settings:
Holder - layer height 0.2mm or 0.3, fill 0.3
Tower - same, average settings really The "spoolholder" is a two piece support system to span the top area of a Printrbot Plus v2.1, it offers rigidity and and two rail accessory beam to the game. It uses #6-32 bolt/nut (x1 each) and 8mmx355mm shaft (x2). The nut goes in the slot, the bolt goes in the hole, the z axes go in the bottoms, and then you've got a baby holder. The "spooltower" is a small tower that I threw together to hold my only two colors of filament that I currently have (black and white) and work with the rail system I had made. I was still getting used to solidworks so it was all I could do to get the design I ended up with, it may not be pretty but it works. It uses the same #6-32 bolt/nut (x1 each, upside down) to fasten to the rails and the top is a 12mm Dia. wooden dowel that is secured with a small screw. Simple and gets the job done.

comments.text: Very nice design and provides a z stability bar. Thank you for posting this item. Note confirmed this fits 12 mm linear bearings.

description.text:
Recently, I purchased some new PLA material and found out that the spoolâs that hold the PLA have changed. They are now more narrow and with a larger OD.  This larger OD interferes with the power and USB  Connectors on the back of my MakerBot.  So, I decided to move the spool to a new location.  
Just print the Main Mounting Bracket (2.5hrs on low print settings) and mount to the table in position you want.  I elected to mount it perpendicular to the back.  Use OEM Spool Bracket and attach to the new Main Mounting Bracket.  
Note; the Main Mounting Bracket is tall enough to accommodate the new spool OD. But, if you have any parts mounted to OD of the spool; just print the extra Spacer part (55minâs on low print settings) to lift spool extra 1/2" higher.

So this was my second project when I was a little better at things, still learning to slightly upscale things enough to compensate for shrinking since I am located in a cold basement. The thingi is a 3 axis brushless motor gimbal for a gopro hero 3 in the skeleton case. Movie!!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LU4G0ZOkrPE

Print Settings:
Fill - 0.8 Layer Height - 0.2 Motors:
2206-140Kv Brushless Gimbal Motor (x2) ~$30
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=43037 2804-210Kv Brushless Gimbal Motor (x1) ~$20
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=43040 The dimensions for the motors can be found on those sites.
They use M2's on one side and M3's on the other. I used M3 hardware and I think a #6-32 (?) for the skeleton case/pitch mount. SimpleBGC Settings: Pitch: P25 I0.3 D33 Power 175
Roll: P33 I0.2 D35 Power 225 I didn't get around to the yaw on this one because it turned out to be too big for the nose of the plane I want to put it in. These settings are high though since it is a decent size rig for a gopro. Mess around with the PID and Power until you get it. Here is a good guide: http://aerialpixels.com/support/alexmos-brushless-gimbal-controller-simplebgc-tuning-guide/

description.text: for zombie party

A mount and blower-style shroud to attach a 40mm fan onto the x carriage of a Bukobot v2.
As far as I know, this will only attach to a single extruder model as it attaches through one of the holes that a dual extruder would normally obstruct. If you have a dual extruder model, then please feel free to adapt this design to work with it and please upload the results for others to use. Update - June 2014:
I just realised that the original upload didn't have the fan mounting plate on the shroud

For this build you will require a 40mm fan and 6 M3 fasteners
  • Attach the shroud to the mount, placing the nut side on the inside of the shroud and tightening enough to allow only intentional adjustment of the shroud
  • Place a fastener through the holes in the fork end of the mount and attach a nut on the underside
  • Attach the fan to the large end of the shroud with 4 fasteners, which should tighten into the plastic without the need for accompanying nuts
  • Slide the mount over the x-carriage plate with the fastener sliding into the notch on the front side and tighten the fastener to restrict movement

remixed_from.author: blomker
remixed_from.title: Kossel Mini NEMA17 Extruder for 1.75mm Filament

description.text:
A direct drive extruder based on a single printed part.
This extruder is part of the StrongPrint the Metal 3D printer http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:329498
Designed in OpenScad to:
  • Be compact & provide a good drive of the wire.
  • Be parametric for different wire diameters.
  • Be parametric for drive wheel diameter.
  • Be extremely easy to implement
  • Use the flexibility of the plastic.
  • Have a good hold of the wire & to be able to handle flexible wire
    Exemple given is for:
  • 1.75mm wire & 0.6mm steel wire
  • MK7 drive gear 11mm diam
  • 608 Bearing from rollerblades with M8 screw
    Print with 3 outside layers, 15% fill ratio & supports

• For if you use 0.6mm wire & M8 bolt & nut with a motor with a bump near the shaft there is a clash between the motor & the nut which require some grinding of the bolt. (to be corrected in next version)
  • For Steel wire use a strong gear & not MK7 or 8 these are not durable enough for this application.

comments.text: nema.scad & bearing.scad have been added. These files are fron the original rostock published by Johann Rochol.
comments.author: kolergy

comments.text:
The Openscad file is totally parametric you can adapt it to what you have.
I made it originally for MK7 compatible gear 11mm diam & 608 bearings from rollerblades attached with a M8 bolt
You might want to wait a day or two before trying it out a it is not yet finalized.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/aSz52BsECEn
asfdsdgfdhsbgSDGfd
EFGSDAGDFSFG

This dock is designed specifically for the iPhone 5 and its new lightning connector. This dock is taller than others in order to accommodate the lightning connector's longer stress relief. This dock includes a chamber for weight such as BBs or lead sinkers and a cover which can be glued into place once the weight has been included. This design is parametric, but I designed it in Alibre CAD so it might not be as easy to modify if you don't have the software. 10/17/12 update: I published a version of this dock for phones with a case: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32610

Print the dock and the cover. 
I designed the cable channel to be narrower at the very bottom so you may need to clean it up with a hobby knife. Trim it so that you can just fit the cable through.
I designed the lightning connector channel to be snug. I had to clean up my channel with a round file just a little before the connector would fit through. Once the connector is in position, run the cable through the cable channel .
Fill the weight chamber with weight of your choice and apply the cover with glue.

comments.text: I'm printing this with a .4mm nozzle, and am having some cosmetic issues with the front plate. The lightning cable hole is at an angle, and gets very close to the front wall at the bottom (only .9mm away). This forces slic3r to create a small V shaped distortion as it tries to fill in such a small gap. If you could update it by thickening the front wall by just a few fractions of a mm, I think it would increase printability.
comments.author: andersonmatt1125

comments.text: Since this is in progress, you might consider adding small tabs (or pegs) to the edge of the cover and small slots to the sides of the cover rest... then you don't need to glue it, it will just bend and snap in.

I had an issue with the filament support, it got stuck sometimes and I could see some missing layers from time to time.
I decided to look for a solution and the best one was from "Sneakypoo" in that thing : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:235925 The all idea is good but not working for me , so I decided to make my own thing. I ended by creating an adapter for the PLA roll it self I used two 6001 bearings ( ExtD 28mm IntD 12mm )
printed with PLA
layer 0.1 mm
speed 35
Nozzel T 230 ( a bit high but to get a smooth finish)
and I m using 03 fans ( two big fans on the sides of the machine and one on the extruder ) Since I have a lot of these rolls I can remove the bearing adapter and put it on the others here is the video to show how it works http://youtu.be/XiOLHdobClM

I used two 6001 bearings ( ExtD 28mm IntD 12mm )
printed with PLA
layer 0.1 mm
speed 35
Nozzel T 230 ( a bit high but to get a smooth finish)
and I m using 03 fans ( two big fans on the sides of the machine and one on the extruder Designed in solidworks 2013 then saved as A STL file , after that repaired in NETFABB BASIC 5.1 and silced with cura 14.03
then printed with my 3D printer ( THINKOCEAN 3D)

My acrylic insulator retainer broke when I tried to tighten the screws on it too much. My thermal insulator was a bit wobbly... So I looked for a thing to print to replace it, but all I found was this
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1004
it should work just the same, but I thought I would update to the newest version (the non-round version)

-Download the STL
-Slice it (I recommend fill rate higher than 0.5 for strength and at least 2 extra shells on every layer for the holes)
-Print it
-Use as is or drill out the holes for the M3 bolts with a 3mm drill to make things smoother. Chances are these holes have shrunk, unless you have "stretch" down to an art.
-Print a few spares (for yourself and your buddies) because it's highly likely that this part is the first to go on most extruders.

comments.text: Is there any function to the big bulk of plastic around the drive wheel? It looks like there is a lot of surplus plastic there that doesn't contribute much. I would prefer that one side of the drive wheel is visible so that if there is ever any slippage, the chewed plastic in the drive wheel can be cleaned out without having to disassemble. I like that this is a relatively simple change to solve the non-adjustable nature of the original design. I would like to modify it to remove the Y axis bearing holders and turn the extruder thru 90° so that I can use this as the basis for a more rigid Z/X assembly (with both sets of shafts rotated 90° so they are on parallel vertical planes). I prefer the bed to be on a separable base plate so the printer can be broken down for transport. Check out the recent discussion on the http://reprap.orgreprap.org smartrap forum. Are you willing to share your source file?

Read more about it on our blog. http://www.perpetualplasticproject.com/blog/2014/4/25/3d-print-the-king The head was modeled in Sculptris (first sculpt ever) and was combined in Rhino with a chess piece from http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-scan-your-head-and-use-it-as-an-chess-piece/?ALLSTEPS

Because the final stl is not a completely merged mesh I used in Cura the Expert Settings - Fix Horrible - Combine Everything Type B in order to prevent holes in the model.  
The hair and head, two different objects in Sculptris, were MeshBoleanUnion'd in Rhino.  
Printing with a raft is recommended to prevent the model from tipping over.

title: Uno Case with Hinged Lid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A simple hinged case for an Arduino Uno, to protect it from static discharge, knocks, wet or conductive surfaces, etc. I have left a single-layer bridge over the captive nut holes because Slic3r currently won't let me tell it not to extrude a hole perimeter into empty space before trying to bridge up to it. This also prevents dust et cetera from entering the case via an un-used hole if left in place. I took dimensions from http://arduino.cc/blog/2011/01/05/nice-drawings-of-the-arduino-uno-and-mega-2560/ and due to a single-digit slip-up in converting mils to mm, had the USB-B port hole offset by about 2mm in my first prototype shown in the photograph, but that was easy to fix with a small blade on my multitool. The Designs I uploaded have been corrected and should fit an Uno in and out easily, even while the lid is on.

• Print out one case and optional lid per Uno.
  • Remove support from relevant holes (I only use bottom-left, bottom-right and top-right holes on my Uno Revision 3 board).
  • Fit your Uno board inside the case using M3x8mm bolts (I used M3x10mm plus a couple of hole-punched bits of cardboard as soft spacer washers between the bolt caps and the board), with an M3 nut in the base for each bolt.
  • Fit the hinged lid with two M3x20mm bolts and two M3 nuts (assuming version 1.1 - I abandoned 1.0 because the second design is stronger).
  • (Optional) If you printed the lid version with slots in it to hold a battery, you can hold a 9V PP3 battery there with a couple of zip ties (I found the ones I had to hand were too short, so I tied one on with an old damaged elastic hairband that I found, after snipping it in half and melting the ends closed). You could also bolt on a pack of AA/AAA batteries if you have one with a mounting hole.
    • Let me know if you want an alternate case version drawn up with room for a shield - I'll need dimensions for the shield though.

title: Orca v0.4x Modular Coolingtower for hotend
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This coolingtower is based on the design made by Chri. Since his design is not compatible with the Orca V0.4x (0.43 in my case), I redesigned the middle and the upper part to be compatible with the standard X-carriage of the V0.43 and hotend v10B. I did not redesign the lower part of the cooling tower, you can use this part as designed by Chri (yellow part in the pictures).

There is no need to drill any holes in the X-carriage (at least in the v0.43 design). Shopping list:
  • 40 mm fan
  • M4 Bolt approx 20 mm with a self locking nut and 2 washers for connecting the cooling tower to the carriage,
  • M3 Bolt and self locking nut for connecting the fan to the cooling tower. Length to be the height of the fan plus an additional 5 mm. Most fans are 10 mm.
    • Parts to be printed:
  • One of the two lower parts as designed by Chri, Turmuntenr.stl or Turmuntenoffen2r.stl (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23590), exact model depending on your hot end.
  • The middle part should be printed with external support only.
  • The upper part can be printed without support.
    • The middle and the lower part are a tight fit, they won't fall apart during printing. The fan should be mounted using only a single M3 bolt.

My Makerbot was having a hard time printing out thin walls with water-tight settings, so I made this simple hollow cube to calibrate again from scratch. The walls of the cube are 1.5mm because that is the minimum thickness I would ever use. (See the OpenSCAD files if you\'d like to change dimensions) While going through the calibration process, I strategically changed one Skeinforge parameter at a time no matter how mundane or obvious the change seemed to be. The process is documented with expected vs. actual results, notes, build times, high res pictures, and download-able gcode files for those interested in SkeinView-ing. You can find it on the Wiki: http://wiki.makerbot.com/skeinforge-calibration-logs 2 Hollow Cubes.stl is for optimizing oozebane or extruder controlling for multi-part prints. (I haven\'t gotten that far, yet.)

If you are new user and/or intimidated by the process of calibrating your Makerbot, I encourage you to document your entire process so that it will be easier for others to have a clear perspective of what you\\'ve done in case you encounter problems.

comments.text: What settings do I change if it's making a bunch of tiny jog prints in between the outer and inner layers in the walls? I've had this problem with other walled boxes I tried to print. it fills the out wall and inner wall but then stutters violently trying to fill the wall.
comments.author: themitch22

comments.text:
change fill
&
gt; infill permimeter overlap (down) and infill width over thickness (up) as well as carve
&
gt; layer height (up) until the Skeinlayer view only has straight lines in the layers with only walls (you don't even need to print it to check). Also, you can shrink the hollow cube down until it's only a few layers so that you g-code generation goes a lot quicker. After the gcode generates with only straight lines, tweak your flow rate until your printer is actually producing liens that have that width over thickness ratio.
comments.author: themitch22

comments.text: I dont think the jogging is necessarily a bad thing, its just not the most time efficient method of filling the walls.  I think it has to do with tweaking  layer height and feed-rate so your optimal result would be 3 straight passes at 0.5mm a piece.  This would be a good question to bring up in the Makerbot Operators google group, as someone might know for certain.

title: Rasberry Pi case mountable on Orca v0.4x
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Raspberry case designed to be mounted on the alu side plating of an Orca v0.4x. I'm using a RPi with a modified version of Prontrface during printing.
Some holes in the case are closed, I don't expect that you will use the audio jack and/or video connector of your RPi (at least I don't). The lids has some holes in order to passive airflow through the case.
Please note that this is a WIP, the alignment of the holes is not perfect (yet). At the moment you can mount the case using 2 bolts.

For an Orca v0.43 you don't have to drill any holes in the aluminium. Print the case and the lid. Mount the case to your Orca using the following parts:
3x M3 8 mm bolt,
3x M3 Plain washers,
3x M3 nuts.
Optional: a 30 cm USB cable to connect to the Gen6 deluxe board (they do exist). The holes in the case are a little bit small, you can use a drill to make hem a little bit wider. Be careful not to use longer bolt, you don't want to short-circuit your Raspberry Pi! The lid is a tight fit in the case, there is not need to use glue or anything. Both parts can be printed without support.

Some of my students are going to be creating a collaborative Star Wars chess set (good v/s evil). They will be uploading their designs to the Thingiverse. To commemorate the chess set I wanted to print something to go along with it. I set this up for dualstrusion so it could have a black base and yellow lettering. I plan on printing this tomorrow and will upload a photo of it once it's done.
If you only have 1 extruder download starwars.stl, but if you want to do dualstrusion you can grab the base and top as separate files here and combine them in RepG.

This is a wooden whistle based on the traditional wooden organ pipe design. The internal pieces are traced from an old organ pipe diagram; they can be laminated together between the two end caps to make a whistle that really whistles. This was cut from 1/8" basswood. UPDATE (May 2011): a full chromatic octave of 13 pipes - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8736
Also I changed the license from all rights reserved to CC-BY-SA.
The design contains two end caps and six internal layers, but the whistle works fine with even just one internal layer.  Assembly photos coming soon.

description.text: This is a hasp. Basically an external lock typically used for bathroom doors.

This consists of 3 pieces. A male piece which has the pin (sliding nob) is to be bolted to the door through its 4, 1/4" OD holes. The female piece, where the pin inserts, is to be leveled with its counterpart (the male pin)and bolted onto the wall. The pin can then slide into and out of the female slot to lock or unlock a foor

description.text:
Create your own Paris with these famous architectures. After the creation of a giant Eiffel Tower (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:254133), we wanted to print more architectures from our city, that everyone could take as an example of a 3D printed object and collects as a souvenir. That's why we created these mini architectures :
  • The Eiffel Tower
  • The Louvre Pyramid
  • The Madeleine Church
  • The Arc de Triomphe
  • The Sacre-coeur Basilica (Montmartre)
  • The Notre-Dame Cathedral

Printed with 0,15 mm of layer height.
Raft for the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de triomphe.
No support.

remixed_from.author: TrevM
remixed_from.title: OpenSCAD ISO metric thread library / functions

title: OpenSCAD ISO metric thread library / functions (updated)

description.text:
Re-worked.
Cleaned up separating into functional sections and adding comments.
You can now chose Rolson or Fairbury wrench (spanner) sizes.
Much faster rendering (details in Instructions).

OpenSCAD 2014.03 has modified polyhedron() command. Use ISOThread.scad to avoid getting 'deprecated' messages, use ISOThreadLeg.scad (Legacy version) for all earlier versions of OpenSCAD. top of file includes calls to make bolts: M10x16, M8x16, M6x12 nuts: M10, M8, M6. simply un-comment a line and build then print, or create your own sizes or include into your own project so you can have threads.
Photos should show black and white nuts and bolts in M6, M8 and M10 sizes, black versions are standard bought steel, white versions are ones I printed in white ABS. This new version is much more modular, it easily allows non ISO thread pitches to be used (functions thread_in_pitch and thread_out_pitch).
Set variable WrenchSizes=0 to get Rolson nut / bolt head sizes as previous version, set WrenchSizes=1 to get Fairbury nut / bolt head sizes (as suggested by obijuan). This version is much faster to render, many thanks to Tafka - clever guy, I used his suggestion, threads are assembled in turns and parts of a turn, OpenSCAD caching loves it. Tests using Windows 7 Home Premium 64 bit with $fn=30
Previous 23/08/2012 OpenSCAD 2012.04.01 (git c869c6e).
-- M10 nut = 9 secs
-- M8 nut = 10 secs
-- M6 nut = 3 secs
-- M10x16 = 2 mins 16 secs
-- M8x16 = 2 mins 7 secs
-- M6x12 = 1 mins 4 secs
New 20/04/2014 (Leg or std):
-- M10 nut = 4 secs
-- M8 nut = 6 secs
-- M6 nut = 5 secs
-- M10x16 = 18 secs
-- M8x16 = 25 secs
-- M6x12 = 23 secs Please use as you wish and enjoy :-)

But My printer is printing 0.2mm larger than expected (New Matter MOD-t) so I'm reducing the XY spacing with the super useful "Horizontal expansion" to -0.2 or -0.3. Using this the thread bits gets very separated and the result is not good.
Unfortunately it's my only way to respect correct dimensions in the thread, so JustKrys work saved me.

description.text:
Wedge shaped stackable boxes with a lid that can be used as a display.
Created to transport and display small objects to a demo outside Fablab Enschede. The lid can be made of transparant acrylic so in case of wind or rain the content can be covered. The lids can hold a text or picture.
The boxes stack nicely with male and female shapes which makes transport easier. size 297 x 297 x 80 / 41 mm (back / front), 6 mm thick plywood, lasercut at Fablab Enschede with 60 W trotec laser and Rhino 3D Design by Wout Zweers www.woutzweers.nl
www.fablabenschede.nl

cut with 60 W laser trotec speedy 300 at Fablab Enschede
parts glued with PVA wood glue

The original was really close but had a few issues that I corrected most importantly making it use at least a PART of the required by pinewood block per the Cub Scout rules, and making sure it stayed UNDER the pinewood derby car size requirements (7" long MAX and 2.75" wide max). I added a few other embellishments to the driver compartment including a dashboard, center console and drive-line "hump". Made the model "self supporting" so you will not need your slicer to add support material if your printer is working right. You will need to size your block to fit in the cavity and that should leave just enough wood for the wheels to attach to the wood block as is required by the rules. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/a16IVAlGRN8

-Perimeters are set to 2
  • Infill can be 10% or .1
  • No support needed
    • Pictures are from a Printrbot Simple Maker XL using PLA. Cut your pinewood block down to minimal 5/16" tall in the center but 1/2" at the wheel attachments, by 6" wide, and width is stock 1 3/4". Use the additional "template" file as a guide. Be sure to line up the wheel slots to the centers of the wheel wells (should only need to cut of one end of the block to get the length). Note: If you work on the original Tinkercad files, you will likely need to use a repair file to fix the mesh. I've upload files that were run through Nettfabb Cloud at https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/

title: RC Shock Protector for the CEN GST MONSTER TRUCK.

description.text:
This is a rc CEN GST monster truck shock (suspension) protector. It must be printed using a flexi filament such as NinjaFlex. It is designed to attach to the suspension unit of the GST RC monster truck and acts to prevent dirt and grime damaging the shock and rubber seals. This helps to prevent shock oil leakage.
I use this on my CEN GST and they work like a charm, haven't even become damaged. Each shock protector required no raft or support structure and will only use 2.5 grams of filament. Print Time @ 0.25mm layer height = 25mins.

title: Leatherman Multi-Tool Bit Set Case / Enclosure

description.text:
Now I won't lose any more Leatherman bits!  
NOTE: to print this at the perfect size, use the following scale:  
x 0.96, y 0.7  (to make it slightly shorter and a bit narrower).  The z scale is perfect, however going up to z 1.1 should still work fine.  
I have a Leatherman Skeletool and a 36-bit set of Leatherman slim hex bits.  The bit set is useful but some bits only fit loosely and are prone to being knocked out of the caddies.  
Because I don't carry a belt pouch, I decided to create this hard case for the two caddies full of bits.  The caddies are offset so one or both can be lifted to get bits out.  
I used hot nails to hold the caddies in so they lift up when I need them, but when I don't need them the plastic enclosure prevents them from falling out.  
This is version 5 of my design.  I printed three of the five versions during development (in black you can see version 3, which had walls so thin they separated from the floor; version 5 [in white] is very rugged).  I am considering adding a space for a simple locking mechanism so the caddies won't flip up without permission.  I don't need it, but you might.  An easy way would be to put a third hot nail in, just in front of the front bit on the top caddy.  
v1 was the wrong size  
v2 was wonderful but the walls liked to separate no matter how it was printed  
v3 had a design error in a new feature I was adding  
v4 had upgraded walls  
v5 had two rectangular primitives added to retain the hot nails more reliably

Tools: 3D printer, stats or needlenose pliers, fire or torch, diagonal cutters Consumable Materials: plastic of your choice, nails. The nails are what will be used to keep the bit caddies from escaping (see my photos). 1) Print at scale (x, 0.96), (y, 0.7), (z, 1.0 to 1.1)
2) Acquire two nails long enough to go through it
3) use stats or similar to hold the nail while you heat it.
4) when hot enough, pass it firmly but slowly through the plastic at just the right spot to go through the bit caddy.
5) pull it out and cut it to length with diagonal cutters
6) heat it again and push it all the way through into the other side Background info: When I noticed the Leatherman 40-bit set came in these two weird caddies, I realized they were made to be slid into a soft belt case like the larger multi-tools. My multi-tool is one of the smaller ones, and I clip it on my pants. So I needed a way to store these bits that wasn't just on loose caddies. I measured the outer dimensions of the bit sets and began designing a generally accurate shaped enclosure for it. As I looked at it from different angles I kept making changes to follow the lines of the two bit caddies. The handles of the bit caddies are made by a technique that also makes a hole through the handles. I decided my bit set case would have them held in by pins so I could lift the first layer out of the way to get to the second layer. The walls are designed to prevent the bits from falling out, and this feature works perfectly!

Python + SolidPy -> OpenSCAD code -> Solid Model

Write the python code to build your solid model. While your write your code and run it, changes to the output can be observed using OpenSCAD with the â€˜Automatic Reload and Compileâ€™ setting checked. Real Madrid Club de Futbol
from http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. Real Madrid Club de Fútbol (Spanish pronunciation: [reˈal maˈðɾið ˈkluβ ðe ˈfuðβol]; Royal Madrid Football Club), commonly known as Real Madrid, or simply as Real, is a professional football club based in Madrid, Spain. Founded in 1902 as Madrid Football Club, the team has traditionally worn a white home kit since. The word real is Spanish for royal and was bestowed to the club by King Alfonso XIII in 1920 together with the royal crown in the emblem. The team has played its home matches in the 85,454-capacity Santiago Bernabéu Stadium in downtown Madrid since 1947. Unlike most European football clubs, Real Madrid's members (socios) have owned and operated the club since its inception. The club is the world's richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €513 million, and the most valuable sports team, worth €2.4 billion (US$3.3 billion).[6][7][8] It is one of three clubs to have never been relegated from the top flight of Spanish football, along with Athletic Bilbao and Barcelona. Real Madrid holds many long-standing rivalries, most notably El Clásico with FC Barcelona and El Derbi madrileño with Atlético Madrid. The club established itself as a major force in both Spanish and European football during the 1950s. Domestically, Real Madrid has won a record 32 La Liga titles, 19 Copas del Rey, 9 Supercopas de España, 1 Copa Eva Duarte and 1 Copa de la Liga.[9] Internationally it has won a record nine European Cup/UEFA Champions League titles and a joint record three Intercontinental Cups, as well as two UEFA Cups, and one UEFA Super Cup.

remixed_from.title: TrailTech Vapor Dashboard/Mount for Suzuki DRZ 400 S/E/K/SM with Fat-bars (1-1/8") 2001-2014

title: TrailTech Voyager Dashboard/Mount for Suzuki DRZ 400 S/E/K/SM with Fat-bars (1-1/8") 2001-2014
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an ultra-compact dash replacement for the Suzuki DRZ 400 made to carry a Trail-Tech Voyager GPS Speedo along with the factory ignition switch and indicator lights.   
This design mounts directly to the oversize handlebar between the clamps. It was designed and tested with Pro-taper fat-bars and Pro-taper handlebar clamps.  
Making the most of this design requires being able to pause your 3D-printer at a specific height/layer to embed the nuts in the bottom part of the mount. This makes for a greatly simplified installation. M5 lock-nuts and allen-head M5 (35 to 40mm long) bolts are recommended along with your original Suzuki and Trail-tech hardware. Also recommend 1 flanged wood screw to lock the top plate in position.   
I personally tested this design on my own motorcycle for over 1 year/1700 miles in all weather/terrain/conditions without any issues and it continues to have miles added to it.

Printed at either 100 micron layer height or 200 microns with skinning for best appearance. Should use a 0.4mm nozzle. All parts print, flat-side-down.
Lots of fillets were used to smooth out printing.
The bottom piece should be paused at 7.5mm to drop the M5 nuts in their respective holes.
When installing on the bike, mount the electronics in the top piece and then bolt the bottom and top pieces together clamping it to the bar. The carrier plate with the Voyager should be added last. I recommend adding thin rubber washers under the voyager and using a small amount of medium-thread-lock when bolting the voyager to the carrier plate. Then slide the carrier plate into place, it should wedge itself snug by the time it's flush with the mount. Then add the wood screw in the hole below the carrier to lock it in place.

description.text: Some special cookie cutter ;)
Dollhouse table and chairs for young kids

To aid in printing, I made the chairs and table in two parts which can be easily assembled after printing. The table top will join to the table base with an interference fit and shouldn't need glue. The chair tops, however, should be glued to the chair bases. I assembled my chairs with the chair-backs at a slight angle (like a real chair) and used epoxy glue to hold them together. I made these to replace some dollhouse furniture that my granddaughters broke. They have essentially the same dimensions as the original, but I didn't replicate the design. They love the new ones and they are fairly indestructible. Update 25Dec15: I added the .STL files to the site, for those that can't use the .thing format. If you use these files, you will likely need to rotate the chair back 90 degrees into the flat position, so you can print it without support.

This is an easy to make 75mm bowl adapter. It is not necessary to turn on supports if the parts are laid out properly. The main part should be upside down and the smaller part should be topside up. Turn up the infill to create a stronger part to your liking.  
You'll need two 3/8-16 nuts and one 3/8-16 x 3" long threaded rod. The best 3/8-16 nuts would be low profile. Finally you'll need a 3/8-16 wingnut to secure the parts when mounted to your tripod.

description.text:
This is a small candy dispenser for small disc shaped candies.
It has a carrying capacity equal to a small vending bag, and has been tested against at least one particular brand. The scad file is near fully parametric, so it can be adjusted for small variations in candy size with other similar shaped candies.
I'd like to thank http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2909 for inspiration.
Update: Tested successfully with M&M's and Reeses Pieces. Skittles are taller, and won't fit with the default numbers in candy.gcode and the first set of parts. Update: I've added room for a spring!
I've uploaded a revised version (candy2.scad) with added code to put holes in the base and slide to house the spring from a pen. I've also more fully commented the parameters that can be adjusted in the file.
I've uploaded the revised stl parts (sp-candyslide and sp-candybot), with increased height to fit skittles. (It still works for the other candies of course.) The same top part fits with these bottom parts.

When skeinforging these parts, for best results, turn towering on, and infill in direction of bridges off. (Also, turn on outside extruded first, which is the default.)
Build the bottom, slide, top, and lid. Clean any loose bits off if necessary. You can choose either candybot.stl and candyslide.stl or sp-candybot.stl and sp-candyslide.stl if you want a spring. The rest of the parts are interchangeable.
Place the slide in the bottom. If you are using the spring version, insert the spring into the hole in the base near the handle opening first. (One spring seems to be enough, but there are holes on either side if you want two.) use a screwdriver or something to compress the spring while you align the slide with the spring and bottom. (It works best with the wide end up, upsidedown from how it is built, so the spring is fully enclosed when compressed.)
Slide the top into the dovetail joints in the bottom. You can glue the top and bottom together, or leave them as is.
Fill the hopper with the contents of one small bag (or a portion of a large bag), and put the lid on it.
Hold the dispenser over your hand, push the knob of the slide in and pull it out, and catch the candy in your hand. Repeat as desired. Sometimes you may have to gently tilt the dispenser slightly to help them shift.
Additional build notes:
Skeinforge-0006 doesn't slice the cone optimally, which may add as much as 10 minutes to the build time. Alternate code is in the OpenSCAD file for a cone that works better with v6. Skeinforge-0007 does a better job on the cone, but unless you've got yours tuned better than I've managed, makes the walls too thin.
The dovetail combined with the round cut tickles a bug in the bridging code. However, the result seems to build anyway, but may need some extra cleaning. It builds perfectly if you disable "infill in direction of bridges" which should make it cross the bridge diagonally.
The spring version of the slide has overhangs around the spring housing. I've cut the "top" set of these overhangs at a strict 45 degree angle. It probably works better if the uncut "bottom" of the slide is above the spring to hold it in better. The other end of the spring is in a hole that can take advantage of bridging, so no cut was made.
Adjusting sizes:
Adjust candyr and candyh for different size candies. Note that these parameters may drastically change the size of the whole part.
To get a smaller hopper, increase overlap, but not by more than candyr or candies might fall out without moving the lever.
To get a larger hopper, increase hheight, make overlap negative, or increase outwall. (Note: overlap has a sign error in the first version fixed in v2, and I accidently left out outleth, will fix in v3.)
Note that if candyr is increased, outwall and doveoffset may also need to be increased or the wall holding the slide in or the cone floor may not be thick enough.

Turns your Android phone into a stereoscope. This thing is mainly for people with high-degree myopia. If you have normal vision then you'd better stick to original OpenDive (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96878).

Print all 3 sections then screw them together with M4 bolts and nuts. Middle section needs supports. The other two can be printed without supports. You may want to change length of the middle section. It will have to be longer if your vision is better than -10D or shorter if your vision is worse than -10D.

Home Depot Shed Hinge.
This is a continuation to the shed repair I guess. First was the Vent grill and now the hinge broke. Only one part broke so far. I will design the second one shortly. The replacement actually came out really nice with all the features of the original.

I printed the hinge on fine print with full fill and support. I used an Afinia so I don't know how it translates to other printers.
Should probably paint the hinge to help with UV degradation.
I will add the files for the second part of the hinge very soon.

Squirrel Squabble is a 2 player print-and-play board game by Rebecca Bissell. 2 players choose their moves that they'll play against each other to try to collect 5 acorns and return home. Mud pits and bulldog will bar the way and you can squabble with your opponent to try to steal their acorns. This edition enhances the game with original 3D printable elements. Rules are included in PDF form. Recommend booklet printing and cutting the Action Cards into separate cards for the players. Original verison available on Board Game Geek at: http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/71981/squirrel-squabble If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays

• Print 10 copies of SSAcorns.stl in a neutral color.
  • Print SSTiles.stl in a neutral color.
  • Glue the tops and bottoms of the SSTiles base-to-base to make 7 tiles.
  • Print Squirrel1Base.stl in one color.
  • Print Squirrel2Base.stl in another color.
  • Print 2 copies of SSTileHome.stl, one in each squirrel color.
  • Print SSCoins.stl twice, one in each squirrel color or print the coins individually.
    • The SSCaseBodyOpen.stl and SSCaseLid.stl are an optional case to hold the pieces and acorns in. The tiles and coins can be enhanced by changing filament colors at specific points in the print.
  • Change filament when printing SStiles.stl (except the home) at a little over 0.5mm, from a darker color (for the mud) to a lighter color.
  • Change the SSTileHome.stl at 4.5mm or higher from a neutral color to the squirrel's color.
  • Change the coins at at little under 0.5mm and a little over 2mm from the squirrel's color to a complimenting color to improve readability.
    • If printing the booklet version of the rules (recommended):
  • Print SquirrelSquabble3DRulesBooklet.pdf double sided on a single piece of paper.
  • Cut the paper in half the long way.
  • Fold the top (with pages 1/2 and 5/6) in half with 1 and 6 on the outside.
    Put the bottom half of the page in it so the 3/4 page in between page 2 and 5 and the cards is sticking out.
  • Then staple the booklet together.
  • Cut the edges of the booklet to make it even all around and separate the cards.
  • Then cut out the Action Cards and use them in the game.
    See photographic illustration.
    • If you like this you should check out my other board game related 3D printables.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316778
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:316780
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166725
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:149656

A stand for Google's Nexus 7 tablet. It works both in portrait as in landscape view

title: Auto Level for Prusa i3x from DIYTechShop

description.text:
I NEVER HAVE TO LEVEL MY BED AGAIN!!! costs less than $8 and takes less than 20 min to 3d print. This is my take on an auto level mount and arm for the Prusa i3x from DIYTechShop. I used a single TowerPro SG90 9G servo (2 pack from amazon is $8) found at:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008Q6Z36Q/ref=oh_details_o03_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 and the stock end stops (Honeywell). I do recommend upgrading to a better micro switch eventually. in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y6XA-D2Zx2Y
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1XyhIbW0TQk hooking it up is actually pretty easy refer to the makerfarm tutorial :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awsI9bMndJA ***this design should work with other DIYTechShop printers.

• print
  • attach mount between extruder and x ideler
  • attach servo (use the screws that came with package, I added pilot holes in the plastic)
  • attach end stop to printed arm (I recommend snipping off the lever so to use only the button) using 3mm or #4-40 screws
  • attach servo arm to servo (use included screws)
  • follow youtube tutorial
    • ** if your servo jerks around like mine did you should enable "#define PROBE_SERVO_DEACTIVATION_DELAY 300" within marlin in config.h

This is a 3D scan of a carved pig I bought in Guatemala. It has a drawer which pulls out of its side. http://youtu.be/MJCwqyym3qk
http://youtu.be/j71rIS9ma1Y

My aunt asked me to print her a pig on my 3D printer (she collects them.) I looked around for a good model on Thingiverse, and didn't see anything that looked great. While we were on vacation in Guatemala, I picked up a wooden pig with a drawer for a belly. I liked it, and decided it was time to throw together a 3D scanner :)  
I built a 3D scanner with the RAMPS 1.4 board from one of my 3D printers, a stepper motor, a rotating platform, and a Canon A480 with CHDK (I plan to put this up as an instructable later.) I scanned in the pig and made the model with 3DSOM and retouched it with Sculptris to add some fine detail and smooth it out.  I scanned the drawer separately, and used OpenSCAD to create the negative space for the drawer (which didn't scan in well.) I may do some additional work smoothing out the drawer.  
Print the pig and the drawer. Depending on the tolerances of your printer you may need to shrink the drawer slightly more.

author: exosequitur

description.text:
WAT?
=
This is a importable module that allows one to create a physical barcode object with just the barcode number as input. Though there is an option to make this as a keyring object, you can just print the bars/lines to embed on any other 3d object of your choice.
My main personal purpose for this is to print / laser cut grocery store VIP "cards". Not just any VIP card though, an anonymized VIP card (even with digits ending in 2600). The larger goal is to get everyone I know to use the same VIP card (polluting their customer database with one large anomalous customer ;)
One note, by default, you want to print in a dark color and supply a light/white background, I usually just put it up to my arm when scanning (my arm would be the spaces, since I have a paler complexion). If you have a darker complexion, use the inverse argument to the barcode() command and it will print the spaces instead of lines. Use a plastic color of white or red (scanners see it as equivalent to white) and your skin will be the lines. The red keychain gallery image is an example of this.
to use the .scad in your own project, here is a sample program:
Frys Card Example:
=
use ; // import the module
//my frys barcode number
//height of 35
//stretch width multiplier of 1
//make it keychain shaped (1)
//don't inverse lines/spaces (0)
//and this is not meant for dxf laser cutter export(0)
barcode(462409702600,35,1,1,0,0);
Arguments
=
Explanation of arguments in order:
barcode = this is the 12 digit barcode
height = the thickness(tallness) of the physical object (assuming 3d-print)
stretch = This is how long you want the object to be
keychain = keychain bit, 0 if no, 1 if yes
inverse = will make the "spaces" the solid (good when a darker background is used)
0 is default of no, 1 means yes
laser = 0 if this is a normal 3d printed file, 1 if this is to be exported to dxf for laser cutter
Help Me!
=
I want to have a collection of 12-digit grocery store VIP card barcode numbers.
You can help me by giving me only the first 6 of the 12 digits (it should start with the number 4) and I can generate an anonymized version that ends with the digits 2600 (taking checksum into account). Just post your VIP cards in the comments section. Please don't post all 12 digits; that would be your whole VIP card, just the first 6 digits (4xxxxx).
I can scout for stores in my area, but I don't have access to some of the more regionalized ones (for instance, I don't have a Piggly Wiggly...or whatever that store is, and yes, if you have one around: I want).
Current VIP card list
=
Below is a list of barcode numbers in my collection so far. Don't fret if you don't have a printer. Just go to any barcode printing website (i.e. http://www.barcoding.com/upc/) and print it on paper if you still want to use these.
Frys/Safeway: 420033402600
Bashes:490029402600
CVS: 487817302600

Acrylic heart with inside jokes on it.  It was made for my friend.

title: 60 Foot Ball - Cat Toy or Sculpture

description.text: It's a 60 foot ball. Yup, a ball with 60 feet. It's a cat toy, or print it larger and use it as a coffee table sculpture. A conversation starter. This is a versatile multi-use thingy. Currently in progress because at the small cat toy size one of the 60 feet did not print correctly. I am going to try printing it slightly larger and see if that works perfectly. Update: I printed it larger and it lost parts of 3 feet in the larger size vs. only part of one in the smaller size (making it a 57 foot ball and a 59 1/2 foot ball respectively, he he). Sorry if you are an extreme perfectionist, because those are numbers that I can live with, it is what it is ;)

I recommend printing this on a fine setting. The one shown in the gallery was printed at .2 layer depth on the slowest/finest setting. I did have one of the 60 feet that did not print perfectly. I am going to try to print it slightly larger and see if the issue is resolved.

author: justme4112

description.text: It is a bed corner set to fix the RepRap carbon print plate (see https://shop.germanreprap.com/en/product?info=303). This carbon plate is delivered with 4 metal clips, unusable on the Replicator Dual (Clone) because the clips are too big and can (will !!!) collide with the hot-end. This corner set is based on the creation by "crux" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278540), but modified especially for the 0.8 mm height of the carbon plate. The corners can be adjusted to fix sideways the carbon plate, so the plate can be still removed and replaced after printing. Further fixing of the plate is not necessary, maybe one standard clip as additional fix on the right bottom (nearly never crossed by the hot end). Update: Carbon_corners_2 added with additional overhanging claw for better fixing of the carbon plate. The additional size is 1 mm height and 0.6 mm overhang. I'm using a mix - with claw on the front (no impact to the nozzle) and without on the back for easier plate removing. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/iiHarL0ntXY

remixed_from.author: JoeyC
remixed_from.title: Both Extruders At Once For Replicator

description.text:
These rhombic dodecahedra are unconnected, yet inseparable. They have been specifically sized for the Dual Replicator, in such a way that both extruders can be used at once (using JoeyC's script), to print different color interlocking polyhedra. 
This thing turns out to be pretty fun to play with; it makes a decent rattle and I enjoy the game of hanging onto one end and trying to swing it to make all six modules stack upright.

If you're using a Dual Replicator (or similar), skein up halfchain3.stl and then use JoeyC's script so that all 6 are printed. If you'd rather print with just one extruder, I'd recommend chain6.stl, or you can open the SCAD file and output any number of modules at any scale. 
This prints beautifully without support, and due to the large bottom face, it sticks to the platform quite well. I had some trouble with Skeinforge, so if you run into problems, I'd recommend using Slic3r (0.9.2 works great on the Replicator).

title: Interstellar Space Jarhead - LightningWater Cannon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The perfect addition to the Technically Proficient Interstellar Space Jarhead.
  • Updated the tread connector. Simpler for an easier print.... Still though, I need to redesign all of the connector, make a brand new one.*..
    • Also, make sure you scale it! Dont have one on hand, so the overall scale most likely isnt correct. I'm guessing 1.5 of uploaded parts? If you know it, please post up. Trying to stay in line with Games Workshop IP Policy. If any GW employee or representative wishes me to remove or alter any designs, let me know and I will comply with expediency. Below I’ve outlined how I tried to comply with their policies.
    .
    Overall - None of these are exact replicas. I tried to add abit of my own take on things or modification to the design. Ei kitbash it abit. Additionally, all models should just be used for painting practice. Practice messing up a paint job on a print, not your actual GW model.
    .
    Copyrights - I tried to make sure a “significant part” was not the same. Style, yes. Copied, no.
    .
    Trademark - I’ve removed all specific Trademarks. Ex: Aquila
    Non-commercial - I’m making no money from this
    .
    Professional Distribution - I’m not a professional artist, using any of these as a portfolio advertisement. Just a hobbiest tinkering
    .
    Damage our brand - Not doing that. GW IP is a pretty cool universe. Hence the reason I wanted to make models that “live” in it.
    .
    Make it clear you’re doing it unofficial - I’m doing this UNOFFICIALLY.
    .
    Use trademarks appropriately - I tried to remove all trademarks
    .
    Derivative Works - I believe most of these models would fall under derivative works, two are three models might not, but I think most do.
    .
    Non-commercial recasting and 3D printing - I have not scanned any of GW’s IP.

I didn't feel like forking over the money for linear rails, so I decided to make a slider. I wasn't too keen on the bearing sliders used in the Cherry Pi printer (although it is a great design) and I wanted something that was pretty much just click and print and you got a slider. Made fro 1515 misumi extrusion Print settings:
Infill: 50%
Perimeters: 3
Top layers: 3
Bottom Layers: 3
Layer height: 0.2mm Features:
-adjustable to compensate for play
-integrated carriage
-integrated fished line tensioner

BOM:
1- carriage assembly
1- carriage adjuster
4- M3 x 8mm screws
2- M3 nuts
1- M3 nylock nut
3- M3 x 25mm screws (only 2 pictured)
  • Print parts.
  • Slide carriage assembly onto aluminum extrusion
  • slide carriage adjuster into the back of assembly
  • screw in 4 m3x8 screws into back of assembly. tighten so assembly moves smoothly along extrusion without any back and forth slop.
  • insert m3x25 screw into side of carriage. Secure with nut and tighten until slop is gone.
  • Insert nylock into bottom front of assembly. May need to be secured with super glue.
  • screw m3x25 screw into nylock with screw head facing down.
    • To tension fishing line, tie around nylocked screw head, wrap around motor and idlers, and tie around upper securing hole. screw in nylocked screw to increase tension.

comments.text: I would also second the separated carriage or at least a belt version. Also it may be more beneficial on having them last longer by moving the rod joint to the center of the slide. It will lower the z height a bit but would definitely prevent wear and slop.
comments.author: FRodriguez96

comments.text:
